history.content:
I would definitely not recommend this schedule. A more manageable schedule that will allow you to digest CS 170 material (important for technical interviews) and have time to recruit in the Fall (assuming you are looking for internships/jobs) would be CS 170, CS 188, with an upper div non-technical class/breadth.

CS 170 is one of the highest workload upper division CS course with 12-20 hrs/week spent (maybe more) on problem sets. CS 162 is also a very heavy workload course and since its a group project based course, you have to work around your team's work schedules as well.

I am a CS Peer Advisor, so feel free to stop by in front of HP Auditorium M/W 2-4 PM if you want to chat more about this!

__

When it comes to project workload, I've found 164 to be significantly harder than 162.

I would definitely not recommend this schedule. A more manageable schedule that will allow you to digest CS 170 material (important for technical interviews) and have time to recruit in the Fall (assuming you are looking for internships/jobs) would be CS 170, CS 168/188, with an upper div non-technical class/breadth.

CS 170 is one of the highest workload upper division CS course with 12-20 hrs/week spent (maybe more) on problem sets. CS 162 is also a very heavy workload course and since its a group project based course, you have to work around your team's work schedules as well.

CS 170 is one of the highest workload upper division CS course with 12-20 hrs/week spent (maybe more) on problem sets. CS 162 is also a very heavy workload course and since its a group project based course, you have to work around your team's work schedules as well.

I am a CS Peer Advisor, so feel free to stop by in front of HP Auditorium M/W 2-4 PM if you want to chat more about this!

children.subject: Personally, I wouldn't recommend that either because CS 164 is also a project heavy course. I wouldn't underestimate how time consuming CS 170 is unless you have a very theoretical/proofy mindset. In addition, CS 170 is a core CS class, so having additional time to digest the material will allow you to appreciate the course a lot more, and perhaps have do better in technical interviews regarding algorithms/DP in the future. Also, keep in mind Fall Recruiting unless you have some return offer lined up that you plan on taking.

I personally think this schedule is fine, even with the added overhead of recruiting : with a good balance of psets and coding/project work, provided the non-technical classes is not too heavy in terms of time commitment.
How about CS 170 and CS 164 with a non-technical class?

history.content:
What is the difference in workload for CS 164 and 162? Is it an okay workload to take CS 170, CS 162/164, and CS 168/188, with an upper div non-technical class? Has anyone taken a similar workload? If not, which other CS courses have lower workloads to be manageable with a schedule like this?

Thanks
history.subject: CS 164 vs 162 Workload
